intro: Acacia latipes, commonly known as the narrow-leaf wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to Australia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The plant features slender, often twisted branches and small, bipinnate leaves that are typically green with a slight bluish tinge. Acacia latipes produces yellow flowers in globular clusters, which are followed by elongated, woody pods containing seeds. It is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
taxonomy_art_desc: Acacia latipes belongs to the kingdom Plantae. Its phylum is Streptophyta, which includes all land plants and is characterized by the presence of true stems, leaves, and roots. Its class is Equisetopsida, a group that includes ferns and their allies, known for their vascular systems and spore reproduction. Its subclass is Magnoliidae, a group of flowering plants that includes many economically important species and is characterized by their diverse floral structures. Its order is Fabales, which consists of plants with distinctive flowers and includes legumes, which often form symbiotic relationships with nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Its family is Fabaceae, commonly known as the legume or pea family, characterized by their pod fruits and often nitrogen-fixing abilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their acorn-like seed pods and often used in traditional medicine and as timber. Its species is Acacia latipes, a specific type of acacia found in certain regions, known for its unique morphological features and ecological adaptations.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia latipes is primarily native to Western Australia. It is found in the southern and western regions of the state, particularly in the areas of the Geraldton and Esperance regions. This plant typically grows in sandy soils and is commonly found in coastal and inland areas. It is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native habitat. Acacia latipes is an important component of the local flora and plays a role in stabilizing the soil in its native environment.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia latipes was mainly introduced to South Africa, where it has become naturalized in certain regions. It is commonly found in coastal and inland areas, particularly in the Western and Eastern Cape provinces. The plant thrives in sandy soils and is often seen growing along roadsides and in disturbed habitats. Due to its adaptability, it has spread beyond its original introduction sites. However, its impact on native ecosystems is still being studied.
